description:
Valve’s Half-Life 2 is still a wonderful milestone of PC gaming more than 20 years after its original release, but it recently got its dated visuals pumped up with a mod that lets you flex the power of a cutting-edge graphics card. In a video sponsored by Nvidia, PCWorld’s Adam goes through the new ray tracing and graphical enhancements and talks with the developers who implemented them.

Half-Life 2 RTX is a free upgrade if you already own the original (and after a million Steam sales, who doesn’t?), though you won’t get all the enhanced goodies unless you’re lucky enough to have an RTX 50-series card. We’re talking ray tracing and path tracing for incredible lighting, plus new in-game assets with mo
title: Hands-on: Half-Life 2 with RTX-powered graphics looks gorgeous

description:
At a glance

Expert's Rating

Pros

  • Very good at vacuuming up fine debris and dirt
  • Fairly compact and easy to maneuver, in and out of the water
  • Reasonably affordable

Cons

  • Spends an inordinate amount of time idling
  • Filter basket is difficult to open for cleaning
title: Smorobot Tank C1 robotic pool cleaner review: Short of greatness

description:
One of the roadblocks preventing adoption of Windows on Arm PCs has been lingering concerns over whether users would be able to run a specific app. Google said Monday that it is formally releasing Google Drive for Arm PCs, removing one of those obstacles.

The release of PCs powered by Qualcomm’s Snapdragon X Elite Arm processors was generally met with approval, though early tests identified several applications that would run slowly or not at all. Google Drive was among them, and was especially called out during early reviews.

Google announced a beta of Google Drive for Arm last year, and today it’s making it generally available. Existing beta users will be upgraded to the stable version, which requires the Microso
title: Google ships Drive for Arm PCs, removing a compatibility concern

description:

Google announced a beta of Google Drive for Arm last year, and today it’s making it generally available. Existing beta users will be upgraded to the stable version, which requires the Microso
title: Google ships Drive for Snapdragon PCs, fixing a key compatibility concern

description:
The Acer Swift X 14 is a lot of laptop. This particular model has a 16-core Intel processor, an Nvidia RTX 4060 GPU, 16GB of RAM, and topping it all off a gorgeous high-res, high-refresh OLED display. Today, B&H is offering it for $949.99, which is an amazing $550 off the retail price.

This 14.5-incher sits somewhere between a premium thin-and-light laptop and a dedicated gaming laptop, with tons of power packed into a chassis that’s still fairly portable at 3.3 pounds. The 2880×1800 OLED screen, with an impressive 120Hz refresh rate, is definitely my favorite feature. And with an Intel Core Ultra 7 155H and Nvidia GeForce RTX 4060 under the hood, plus 16GB of RAM and 1TB of SSD storage, it has more than enough oomph to make use of t
title: Acer’s OLED gaming laptop with RTX 4060 is a whopping $550 off

description:
Last week, Microsoft sent out a new preview version of Windows 11 to members of the Windows Insider Program. This one only rolled out to those on the Canary Channel, which is the most experimental and unstable channel in the Insider Program.

One of the improvements in the preview update is faster decompression of ZIP files when using File Explorer’s built-in decompression tool. Reportedly, the difference is greatest and most felt when unpacking archives that contain lots of smaller files.
title: Windows 11’s File Explorer will unpack ZIP files much faster soon

description:
Everyone needs a flash drive, but few want to spend big on a flash drive, and few want a chunky drive that sticks out like a thumb. If that’s you, then you can’t do better than this Samsung FIT Plus, which is absolutely tiny and only costs $21 right now for 256GB. Amazon has it on sale, slashed down in price by 40%, which is a massive discount that makes this high-performance device truly affordable.

It feels like not too long ago when digital storage was quite costly, yet now you can get 256GB for the price of a bucket of wings from Popeye’s. The Samsung FIT Plus is compact, too, putting the “thumb” in “thumb drive.” It’s not only spacious enough to carry numerous movies, files, and folders, but also tiny enough to slip into any pocket unnoticed.

As for
title: Samsung’s ultra-compact 256GB USB flash drive is a steal for just $21

description:
If you’re like me, you don’t use Facebook as often as you once did—in fact, it’s probably been months (or years!) since you last logged in. Facebook isn’t what it used to be, so I don’t blame you. But it still sucks to miss out on messages, invitations, and what not.

What can you do if you don’t want to check in on Facebook but still want to be aware of stuff happening to your account? There’s a simple solution called Notification Settings, which sends out email alerts about what’s been happening on Facebook that you might be interested in.

You decide what you want to be notified about, such as Messages, Events, and Friend Requests. You can also choose whether you want to receive notifications by email or text message. Here’s how to set it up:
title: Stopped checking Facebook? How to get email alerts for messages and invites

description:
Philips Hue appears ready to expand its line of home security devices, with clues to the manufacturer’s plans hidden within its own app. 

The leak details an unannounced product that would round out Hue’s existing catalog of security cameras, floodlights, and motion and contact sensors: a video doorbell, which would mark a logical next step in terms of brand’s smart security lineup. 

As HueBlog.com reports, intel about the purported doorbell was discovered by a reader doing a deep dive into the Philips Hue app. Details about the device remain sketchy, but we can be reasonably sure it’s in the pipeline. 

For starters, it appears the doorbell offers both Bluetooth and Wi-Fi connectivity,
title: Is Philips Hue about to unleash its first video doorbell?

title: Addlink P21 review: This affordable, portable SSD looks great

description:
Steam is, or at least it’s supposed to be, something of a walled garden. Like Apple’s App Store for iPhones or the various console game stores, items listed on the store are supposed to be safe, if not necessarily good. The implicitly carry Valve’s seal of approval. But a couple of recent instances of full-on malware being hidden in Steam games is starting to take the shine off.

Back in February there was a free-to-play game that popped up on a Steam listing with stolen assets, spreading malware to downloaders that triggered antivirus and apparently managed to steal Microsoft and Steam login info. Bleepin
title: Malware strikes again. I’m starting to worry about Steam’s lax security

description:
Experts say a clear desk helps boost productivity, and there’s no better way to declutter your workspace than by swapping out your laptop or desktop tower for a tiny little compact mini PC. It won’t even cost you that much if you hit a good deal—like this one.

Right now, Amazon has a special discount for the Acemagician M1 mini PC, which is now just $309 (was $399). That’s 23% less than its original MSRP and worth it for a budget device with this much power. (You’ll need Prime for this deal. Don’t have it? Start a free trial right now!)

What makes the M1 mini PC such a winner? It comes with a middle-of-the-road AMD Ryzen 7 6800H processor and 16GB of DDR5 RAM, which is more than enough to run
title: This Ryzen 7 mini PC with triple 4K support is on sale for $309

description:
There are good deals, and then there’s this crazy discount on Lenovo’s IdeaPad Pro 5i at B&H. Now just $1,099, this configuration is fantastic and usually only available this cheap on days like Black Friday.

This laptop is a rocket for productivity, gaming, and everyday use. It all starts with a 16-core Intel Core Ultra 9 185H processor alongside 32GB of LPDDR5X RAM, powered further by an Nvidia GeForce RTX 4050 graphics card, and rounded out with a 1TB SSD. That’s an amazing setup with tons of power and speed. You’ll never complain about Windows startup again, and your apps will launch in a blink. Even demanding apps like Adobe’s creative tools will be smooth on this laptop.

The display is gorgeous, too, with its 16-inch OLED panel
title: Lenovo’s RTX laptop with Ultra 9 CPU and 32GB RAM is $600 off today

description:
The firewall is one of the most important security features in a computer environment.

In the classic sense, a firewall is set up on an appliance, such as a computer that fulfills just a single, narrowly defined task — those found in companies, public authorities, and scientific institutions, for instance. A firewall of this type monitors the connection between two networks, such as the internal LAN and the internet, to prevent against unauthorized access.

There are also personal firewalls such as the one that’s preconfigured in Windows, or available as freeware or as a paid software solution.

In contrast to a classic firewall, a personal firewall does not protect an entire network, but only the individual computer on which it is installed. It’s the barrier that prevents any harmful elements from accessing the files that you
title: Is your Windows PC’s security firewall good enough? An explainer

description:
Some laptops now have eUFS storage. Unlike the more common NVMe PCIe SSD that we see in most laptops these days, eUFS storage is soldered to the motherboard and isn’t upgradable. Not ideal.

There are other potential concerns as well. In theory, eUFS storage is slower than NVMe SSD storage connected to a PCIe socket. But eUFS has some benefits, too, like promising lower power usage.

I reviewed the Samsung Galaxy Book4 Edge last year, which was one of the first big laptops with eUFS storage, and I was pleasantly surprised by its performance. Is eUFS storage, with all its shortcomings, a deal-breaker on a laptop then? Here’s what you need to know.
title: Phone-style soldered storage is in laptops now. It’s better than I expected

description:
TL;DR: Use this exclusive code LEARN to get lifetime access to Babbel’s 14 language offerings for only $124.99 (reg. $599) through March 31.

Did you start the year off wanting to learn a new language ahead of a vacation or to land a new job? We’re here to check on that. If learning through Duolingo has taught you nothing other than random words and phrases, you may want to switch to this
title: Babbel might actually make you want to keep up with your language lessons
